INTRODUCTION

Development Area 12 is an office building site in Charles Center. In offer -
ing this area now, the Baltimore Urban Renewal and Housing Agency makes
available another of the most attractive investment opportunities in dOWIl'-’:
town Baltimore, at a time when Charles Center's development is assured.
Three buildings have been completed, five are under construction, and four
more are about to start construction. The Civic Center, containing a
13,000-seat coliseum and 100,000 square feet of exhibition space, and
facing Area 12 across Hopkins Place, was opened in October, 1962.

Within Charles Center, Area 12 is located to take full advantage of the
long-term investment safeguards that have been designed into the basic
Charles Center plan--high density of development, open space, and care-
fully controlled flows of pedestrian and auto traffic. Moreover, the de-
velopment of area 12 will be tightly linked to other portions of Charles
Center and to the major existing elements of Downtown Baltimore. Thus,
Area 12 has been designed to share fully in the potential generated by
Charles Center, the Civic Center, and the several other revitalization pro-
grams underway for all of Baltimore's central business district.

Charles Center is the keystone of Baltimore's plans for its central core,
where private and public interests are making a concerted effort of re-
vitalization and improvement. This program includes the Civic Center,
the Mount Vernon Urban Renewal Project, a downtown campus for the Uni-
versity of Maryland professional schools, Monument Square and Court
House Plaza, an expressway network, and the proposed redevelopment of
the Inner Harbor. Among the other renewal projects close to Charles
Center are two industrial parks for expansion of close-in areas for whole-
saling trades and light industries. In 1965, the Metropolitan Transit
Authority will present a comprehensive plan for publictransportation con-
taining major implications for downtown as an elementof the unifiedmetro-
politan area.

Throughout the entire Downtown revitalization program, public and private
efforts have been focused and coordinated at all levels. Today, the City of
Baltimore, acting through its Urban Renewal and Housing Agency, invites
your interest regarding Charles Center Development Area 12. The agencies
of City government, together with business and civic groups, are ready to
help you measure your opportunity and express your interest in the unique
investment advantages afforded by Charles Center.
